bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 24, 1875

div1.p: Reed discusses his future life in the Army and asks Emilie Lawrence to marry him.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 24, 1875
div1.p:
After a short
and pleasant trip of about
24 hours duration, I arrived
at this destination just one
week ago. My sister and her
little children were anx-
iously awaiting my recep
arrival and accorded me a
very warm reception. I
have talked myself almost
out of breath, narrating
my wonderful adventures of
the past few years, and try-
ing to amuse the children
with remarkable tales of
New York City-life. Have, also,
had the pleasure of grasping
the hands of a few old ac-
quaintances & some young
acquaintances. The latter of
these were mere children
when I last visited this place,
but have now bloomed into
womanhood & manhood.
I never felt old age weigh-
ing more heavily on my shoul-
ders than when I am intro-
duced to “Mr or Miss So & So”
whom I only knew as infants
in their mothers' arms. I am
sure that I shall soon be
grey. The thought causes me
to cry aloud with the poet;
“Oh! for one hour of youthful joy,
Give back my twentieth spring;
I'd rather laugh, a fair-haired boy,
Than reign, a grey-beard King.”

Notwithstanding that I
have been made to reflect
on my “ancient days,” I never
had a more pleasant visit,
(of course, my visits to Mur-
freesboro excepted,). There
are two young ladies, of about
18 summers in the house, so that there is
but little danger of my having
the “blues,” even if I was so
disposed.

This much of my letter
by way of a preface. Prepare
yourself for the perusal of
the remainder; nay more,
when you have read thus
far, I earnestly request that
you seek some quiet apart-
ment and a comfortable chair;
that then ridding your mind
of every disturbing thought,
you carefully read and
seriously ponder all my
words. Be patient with me;
hear all I have to say and then
judge me accordingly. You
may, at first, think it strange
that I should speak of my
future life and prospects; but
I hold ideas different from
many young men- In approach-
ing so momentous a subject,
I believe that I should reveal
everything within my knowledge,
or else I know not how you
can possibly arrive at a sen-
sible & sound conclusion. This
opinion of mine will explain what
immediately follows. You know
that I have will soon enter
the medical corps of the U.S.
Army- It is more than prob-
able; nay, it amounts almost
to a certainty that I shall
spend the next ten or fifteen
years of my life in this ser-
vice. Circumstances over which
I have no control and concer-
ning which I possess no knowl-
edge may, on the one hand,
cause me to resign my of-
fice in a few years, or, on the
other hand, lead me to remain
in the Army all my life; the
position being one which I
can retain as long as I
choose or resign whenever
it shall seem fit. Heaven
alone knows which of these courses
I shall pursue.

And now I have determined,
Miss Emilie, to solve the “mys-
tery” of which I spoke in my
last letter, and I do it with
“fear & trembling.” Never did I
approach a task with greater
misgivings or less hopes. In for-
mer letters I have spoken of
my admiration for you in very
plain terms. It is needless for
me to say that I knew you but
to admire you. A more exten-
ded acquaintance has dem-
onstrated to me the beauty of
your character, your womanly
worth, the purity of your
Christianity, the charm of your
intellect, and has changed the
feeling of friendly apprecia-
tion into one of -- shall I say
love? Do you start at the word?
I pray you, repress your
rising indignation and hear
me further. No one could more
fully appreciate my utter un-
worthiness of even your
Esteem than I do, at this moment.
Yet I feel that, though you should
spurn my affection, I should
never be ashamed of having
revealed my love to so noble
a woman. It is for this reason
that I tell you that there is no
burden I would not gladly bear
for your sake; no battle of life
that I would fear to fight in
your behalf; no trial that I would
not willingly accept. Do not
think that I am unaware of
the very great import of my
words. Believe me I have given
this subject much thought, by
day & by night, & have weighed
it, in all its aspects, as care-
fully as it was possible for
me to do. I know that it will
receive equal consideration
at your hands. 'Tis true you
will say that you have known
me but for a short time and
have had but little, very little op-
portunity of forming a just
estimate of my character. To
establish this in a clear & un-
mistakable light would be my
sweetest endeavour. What
more remains to me than
to offer you a true heart and
a true hand for your accep-
tance or rejection. And I beg
of you that you frame your
answer according to the un-
mistakable utterance of your
heart & the best dictates of
your judgement. Whether fav-
orable or unfavorable, I shall
accept it as sincere.
div1.closer: As ever, your very true friend, Walter Reed.
